title: Queen wanted to say ‘Good evening Mr Bond’ during Olympics filming
text:
Queen Elizabeth II told director Danny Boyle she wanted a speaking part (Picture: Hello/ BBC)

Queen Elizabeth II’s dressmaker and confidante has revealed how the monarch chose her own lines for the 2012 Olympics James Bond sketch.

Angela Kelly revealed that the 93-year-old royal said yes ‘immediately’ when director Danny Boyle asked for her to star in the Opening Ceremony scene.

The short clip shows Daniel Craig greeting the Queen and seemingly escorting her from the Palace to a helicopter, where a stunt double then takes over.

Ms Kelly recalled: ‘[The Queen] was very amused by the idea and agreed immediately. I asked then if she would like a speaking part.

‘Without hesitation, Her Majesty replied: “Of course I must say something. After all, he is coming to rescue me.”

The monarch was ‘rescued’ by Daniel Craig in the sketch (Picture: BBC)

She said the line: ‘Good evening, Mr Bond’ (Picture: BBC)

‘I asked if she would like to say “Good evening, James”, or: “Good evening, Mr Bond”, and she chose the latter, knowing the Bond films.’

She then relayed the news to Mr Boyle, adding: ‘I think he almost fell off his chair when I said that the Queen’s only stipulation was that she could deliver that iconic line.’

Ms Kelly has written a book on her life assisting the Queen, entitled The Other Side of the Coin: The Queen, the Dresser and the Wardrobe.

In another extract, published in Hello! magazine, the dressmaker revealed how she wears in the monarch’s shoes and previously used Yorkshire Tea to dye the royal christening dress.

While on one occasion, she was struggling to find trimmings for the Queen’s ascot hat and drew inspiration from a plant pot in the room.

Extracts of Angela Kelly’s book have been published in Hello! magazine (Picture: PA)

Ms Kelly revealed her close bond with the monarch (Picture: Getty Images)

Ms Kelly said: ‘I went looking for Paul Whybrew, the Queen’s Page, for a solution. I found him in Her Majesty’s storeroom, where something immediately caught my eye.

‘In a corner, a modest plant pot contained snake’s-head fritillaries in exactly the same cerise shade as the Queen’s Ascot outfit. I couldn’t believe it.’

The fritillaries were made of silk and so after they had been ‘well dusted’, they were applied to Her Majesty’s hat.

Ms Kelly also revealed the Queen’s sense of humour, stating that she once played an April Fool’s joke on her by placing a cuddly toy kookaburra on her balcony while they were in Australia.

When the monarch realised the bird wasn’t real, she immediately told her aide: ‘You’re sacked!’ before turning to Prince Charles and exclaiming: ‘Angela has had me!’

Michelle Obama and the Queen were pictured with their arms around each other (Picture: Rex /Shutterstock)

Silk flowers were used to decorate the Queen’s hat at Ascot (Picture: PA)

Ms Kelly said: ‘I’m pleased to say the toy is with us in Windsor Castle and has pride of place on the back of the sofa in the Queen’s sitting room.

‘I laugh to myself every time I see it.’

The book also discusses the Queen’s meeting with Michelle Obama during a state visit to the UK in 2009, in which the pair were pictured with their arms around each other.

According to Ms Kelly, the tactile moment was down to Her Majesty’s ability to make ‘everyone feel so relaxed’.

She described an ‘instant and mutual warmth’ being shared between the two women, before noting that in that particular situation ‘there is no protocol that must be adhered to’.

Hello! magazine is now available to buy (Picture: PA)

Ms Kelly said: ‘In reality, it was a natural instinct for the Queen to show affection and respect for another great woman.

‘When fondness is felt or the host of a State Visit goes to guide Her Majesty up some steps, it truly is about human kindness and this is something the Queen will always welcome warmly.’
